title: SB 127
content: The State of California enacts the following. The Legislature acknowledges that many areas in California are disproportionately affected by drought due to heavy reliance on overdrafted or contaminated groundwater basins. Many areas in California are disproportionately impacted by drought due to reliance on overdrafted or contaminated groundwater basins. State grant and loan programs assist communities with water needs, but there is no similar assistance for individual homeowners with groundwater wells who cannot afford conventional loans for water supply improvements. The program created by this act aims to provide low-interest loans, grants, or both to individual homeowners for safer, cleaner, and more reliable drinking water and wastewater treatment. Actions may include digging deeper wells, improving existing wells, addressing contaminants, or connecting to a local system. Chapter 6.6 of the Water Code establishes a Water and Wastewater Loan and Grant Program to provide low-interest loans and grants for various purposes such as extending service lines, connecting to water systems, and closing abandoned septic tanks and wells for health and safety compliance. The Water Code's Chapter 6.6 establishes a program for low-interest loans and grants for purposes like connecting to water systems, closing abandoned septic tanks and wells, and improving groundwater wells with treatment systems if needed. The Water Code's Chapter 6.6 establishes a program for low-interest loans and grants for purposes like connecting to water systems, closing abandoned septic tanks and wells, and improving groundwater wells with treatment systems if needed. The board may adopt regulations necessary for these purposes, including deepening, improving, or installing treatment systems for groundwater wells exceeding drinking standards. The Water and Wastewater Loan and Grant Fund is created in the State Treasury for expenditure according to Chapter 6.6 of the Water Code. Eligible loan applicants must meet specific criteria. An eligible applicant for a loan from the Water and Wastewater Loan and Grant Fund must have a household income below the statewide median, own the residence, be unable to obtain financial assistance from private lenders, lack personal resources for improvements, and demonstrate an ability to repay the loan. To qualify for a loan from the Water and Wastewater Loan and Grant Fund, applicants must have a household income below the statewide median, own the residence, be unable to get financial help from private lenders, lack personal resources for improvements, and show the ability to repay the loan. Loans granted must be secured by a mortgage on the residence, repaid within 20 years with a 1 percent interest rate, and maintain homeowner's insurance on the property. The board may contract with a private financial institution to provide loans under this chapter, using funds from the Water and Wastewater Loan and Grant Fund for loan guarantees. Eligible grant applicants must have a household income below 60% of the statewide median, own their residence, and be unable to secure financial assistance from private lenders. The board may contract with a private financial institution to provide loans under this chapter, using funds from the Water and Wastewater Loan and Grant Fund for loan guarantees. Eligible grant applicants must have a household income below 60% of the statewide median, own their residence, and be unable to secure financial assistance from private lenders. Grant recipients must repay the grant amount if they sell the residence within five years or return any unused grant funds. $10 million is transferred from the General Fund to the Water and Wastewater Loan and Grant Fund. A grant recipient must repay any unused funds. $10 million is transferred to the Water and Wastewater Loan and Grant Fund. An urgency statute is enacted to provide access to clean water during California's drought. To ensure access to clean water during California's drought, an urgency statute is enacted for immediate effect. A new section is added to the Public Resources Code defining "water project" as a project funded with proceeds from the Water Quality, Supply and Infrastructure Improvement Act of 2014. For the purposes of this section, a "water project" refers to a project funded with bonds from the Water Quality, Supply and Infrastructure Improvement Act of 2014. The procedures outlined in subdivision (c) apply to legal actions challenging the certification of an environmental impact report or approvals for a water project. The Judicial Council must establish procedures for resolving legal actions challenging the certification of an environmental impact report for a water project within 270 days. Environmental impact reports for water projects must include a notice in at least 12-point type. The draft and final environmental impact report for a water project must include a notice in not less than 12-point type stating that certain comments filed after the public comment period may not be considered. Judicial actions challenging the certification of the EIR or project approval are subject to specific procedures outlined in the Public Resources Code. The draft and final environmental impact reports for a water project must include the full text of specific sections as an appendix. Within 10 days of releasing the draft report, an informational workshop must be held by the lead agency. Additionally, a public hearing must be conducted within 10 days before the close of the public comment period, with a transcript included in the final report. Following the public comment period, a commenter on the draft environmental impact report can request nonbinding mediation within five days. The mediation must involve the lead agency, applicant, and all relevant commenters, and must be completed within 35 days of the comment period closing. The request for mediation should specify the areas of dispute to be mediated. (A) Mediation can be requested by a commenter within five days of the public comment period closing. The lead agency will choose retired judges or experts with experience in land use and environmental law or science to conduct the mediation. The applicant is responsible for covering the mediation costs. Each area of dispute identified by the commenter will be addressed in a separate mediation session. (D) A mediation session will be conducted for each area of dispute with the parties requesting mediation. The lead agency must adopt any agreed-upon measures as a condition of approval. Written comments submitted after the public comment period will not be considered unless they address specific criteria. The lead agency does not have to consider comments submitted after the public comment period, unless they address new issues raised in the response to comments, new information released by the public agency, or changes made to the project after the comment period. The lead agency must consider changes to the project made after the public comment period, proposed conditions for approval, new information not previously known, and file the required notice within five days of the last project approval. The lead agency must file the required notice within five days of the last project approval and prepare the record of proceedings, with costs covered by the applicant. The lead agency must make the draft environmental impact report and related documents available to the public in an electronic format within three business days of its release. Any additional documents related to the report must be accessible within five business days of their preparation or receipt by the lead agency. The lead agency must provide the draft environmental impact report and related documents in an electronic format within three business days of release. Copyright protected documents not prepared for the project do not need to be electronically accessible, but an index must be available electronically listing where hardcopies can be reviewed. The lead agency must convert non-electronic comments into electronic format within seven days and make them available to the public. Comments not considered do not need to be included in the record of proceedings. Within five days of filing the required notice, the lead agency must certify and provide an electronic copy of the record to a party upon request. A reasonable fee may be charged for the copy. Within 10 days of receiving a complaint or petition, the lead agency must lodge a copy of the certified record with the superior court. Within 10 days of receiving a complaint or petition, the lead agency must lodge a copy of the certified record of proceedings with the superior court. Any disputes over the content of the record will be resolved by the superior court, and parties must file a motion to augment the record if necessary. The contents of the record are outlined in Section 21167.6. The court shall not stay construction of a water project unless it poses an imminent threat to public health and safety, as outlined in Section 21167.6. The court may stay construction of a water project if it poses a threat to public health and safety or if important Native American artifacts or historical values are at risk. The court may enjoin specific activities of a water project that pose a threat to public health, Native American artifacts, or historical values. Any challenge to a subsequent project approval must follow Chapter 6 requirements. An action to challenge a decision of the lead agency for a subsequent project approval must adhere to Chapter 6 requirements. No reimbursement is needed for this act as local agencies can levy charges to cover mandated services.
